Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer's decision properly accounted for the best interests of the children in exercising H&C discretionary powers
Legal_Rule: The standard of review is reasonableness simpliciter; decision must consider factors within legislative constraints
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly consider best interests of children; introduction of improper threshold of irreparable harm
Grounds_for_Claim: Best interests of children under humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision lacked procedural fairness by ignoring relevant factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Potential harm to children due to separation, presence of father in Canada
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 25(1)
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of H&C application based on inadequate consideration of children's best interests
Court_Result: Application allowed; case remitted to a different visa officer for reconsideration
Legal_Rule_Source: Baker v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration), [1999] 2 SCR 817; Suresh v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration), [2002] 1 SCR 3
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different visa officer
Claimant_Status: Applicant in Canada seeking H&C relief
Applicable_Process: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds application process
Governing_Rule: Reasonableness standard per Baker and Suresh
